page.title: 01LANDSCAPE.
page.content: HINDRINGHAM is a small village built upon two low hills. A stream running from a natural spring bisects the village before running into the River Stiffkey. { The village is built largely in red brick and flint with pantiled roofs. A few modern houses are in plain red brick. The fields are mostly arable with few hedgerows. Blocks of woodland survive on the perimeter of the village. Some trees have been planted in 1984 to take the place of hedgerows that have been uprooted in the last decade. To the West are distant views of fields at Walsingham, To the North there are distant views of Cockthorpe and in one or two higher places one may get a glimpse of the sea at Stiffkey.
